earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Focal epilepsies are the most common form observed and have not generally been considered to be genetic in origin. Recently, we identified mutations in DEPDC5 as a cause of familial focal epilepsy. In this study, we investigated whether mutations in the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) regulators, NPRL2 and NPRL3, also contribute to cases of focal epilepsy.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Ricos MG
earliestArticle.dc:title: Mutations in the mammalian target of rapamycin pathway regulators NPRL2 and NPRL3 cause focal epilepsy.

dc:description:
*NPRL2* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant focal epilepsy, a form of epilepsy characterized by seizures that are localized to one area or side of the brain, in 2016 (Ricos et al., PMID: 26505888). Of note, *NPRL2* is a member of the GATOR1 complex, which also includes *DEPDC5* and *NPRL3*. Each of these genes have an asserted relationship with autosomal dominant focal epilepsy (PMID: 23542697, 26505888). 

Ten variants in *NPRL2* (4 missense, 2 splice site, 3 nonsense and 1 frameshift) that have been reported in 12 probands in eight publications are included in this curation (PMIDs: 26505888, 27173016, 28199897, 29281825, 30093711, 31835056, 34376795). Variants in this gene have been observed to segregate with disease in families, but with incomplete penetrance (PMIDs: 26505888, 27173016, 28199897, 34376795). Additionally, several individuals with focal epilepsy and variants in *NPRL2* have been reported to have focal cortical dysplasia (PMIDs: 27173016, 30093711, 29281825, 37259768). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *NPRL2* and autosomal dominant focal epilepsy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

This classification was approved by the ClinGen Epilepsy GCEP on the meeting date July 18, 2023 (SOP Version 9).
